ygData.subject: Heard Brewing was nerfed, is pottery still profitable?
ygData.msgSnippet: Heard Brewing was nerfed, is pottery still profitable as of this morning? ... From: Sean Kennedy [mailto:orang@jps.net] Sent: Thursday, July 08, 1999 2:56 PM
ygData.messageBody:
Heard Brewing was nerfed, is pottery still profitable as of this morning?

-----Original Message-----
From: Sean Kennedy [mailto:orang@...]
Sent: Thursday, July 08, 1999 2:56 PM
To: EQ_Potters@onelist.com
Subject: Re: [EQ_Potters] You're here!


From: "Sean Kennedy" <orang@...>


-----Original Message-----
From: Erik Sinda <eriksinda@...>
To: EQ_Potters@onelist.com <EQ_Potters@onelist.com>
Date: Thursday, July 08, 1999 7:51 AM
Subject: Re: [EQ_Potters] You're here!


>From: "Erik Sinda" <eriksinda@...>
>
>
>How I make 60pp an hour in Halas (as a barbarian shaman with 71 cha):
>
>2 large blocks of clay = 1gp 1sp 7cp * 2 = 2gp 3sp 4cp
>1 large bowl sketch = 1sp 2cp
>1 water flask = 1sp 2cp
>
>total cost for unfished mixing bowl (no pie tins here) = 2gp 5sp 8cp
>
>1 firing sheet ~ 1sp 2cp (I don't remember this figure, exactly)
>
>total cost for finished mixing bowl = 2gp 7sp
>
>Average selling price to NPC in Halas ~ 8gp 5sp
>
>Net profit per mixing bowl ~ 5gp 8sp
>
>On average (no exageration) I can make 20 attempts at mixing bowls and
>achieve 19 successes in under 10 minutes (with 148 skill). Let's say that
>it takes me 10 minutes because I'm working slowly.
>
>19 bowls * 5.8gp = 110.2gp
>
>About 11 pp. This makes about 66pp per hour. That's if I'm not working at
>peak speed... but to be fair, if there's a line for the wheel or kiln, or
if
>I'm talking to a friend at the same time, that figures not going to be that
>high. Most of the time, though, I do this at non peak hours, which means
no
>line _or_ friends... :)
>
>I go mixing bowls all the way. I'm only level 9, but I almost never have
>less than 30pp on me any more.
>
>Baladan
>Barbarian Shaman of Erollisi Marr


I wanted to try mixing bowls, but I don't see the sketches for them
in N. Freeport.
